We have become a nation addicted to anger. Violence is not only normalized/expected, but even regular interactions on the street or work have become venues for confrontation. No doubt we have disagreements in our society, but let‚Äôs not lose sight of the decency between us. END

But I make a New Year‚Äôs resolution to do better and commit to having a talk with my boys. Though it‚Äôs not just how we talk to our kids but also what kind of example we set for them. That is where we as a county are clearly letting down our children.9/10

Yes the schools play a role, but it‚Äôs important for parents to have these tough conversations with our kids. I‚Äôve struggled to find the right words to talk to my little boys. I often give excuses that they are ‚Äútoo little to understand‚Äù or maybe when they get ‚Äúa little older‚Äù8/10

Our county prosecutor Scott Coffina had some powerful reflections on the need to promote decency as a society. I agree wholeheartedly that it feels like we are losing touch with how to just treat each other with respect and decency.7/10 https://burlpros.org/statement-from-prosecutor-coffina-concerning-the-discovery-of-swastikas-and-related-hate-speech-in-marlton-middle-school/

This deeper understanding is needed, but not just for the students that may have been involved, but for everyone. We cannot fight hate if we are only reactionary. Instead of Whack-a-mole actions after the fact, we need to confront how we teach and internalize tolerance. 6/10

The school has made clear ‚ÄúIn addition to punitive consequences, any involved students will receive lessons‚Ä¶in understanding the gravity and hurtfulness of their actions, along with participation in restorative practices intentionally designed to deepen this understanding.‚Äù5/10

But we as adults must work harder not only to ensure that our kids are not exposed to hate, but that they do not tolerate or even further it. As far as I know we don‚Äôt know who drew the swastikas but we confront the possibility that it was a child that did it. 4/10

Just a few weeks ago a swastika was found in the parking lot of a synagogue nearby. A sixth grader was the one who discovered it.  That breaks my hearts to know that a child came across that threat. 3/10 https://twitter.com/andykimnj/status/1467578042004422660 QT @AndyKimNJ A sixth grader just found this disgusting hate at a synagogue in my community. We must all stand united against threats to Adath Emanu-el and all communities. As we reach the end of Hanukkah, I ask that you join me to show that love and unity are everywhere, not hate. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FF3icnwXIAI6POc.jpg

Parents everywhere pray the walls of our schools can keep out the hate, but incidents like this give us worry because they remind us that we cannot perfectly shield our kids from the hurt out in the world. It particularly hurts to see this hate in the town where I grew up.2/10

Two swastikas were just found drawn in boys‚Äô bathroom at Marlton Middle School. ‚ÄúHitler was right‚Äù written by a stick figure with X‚Äôed out eyes and the word ‚ÄúJew.‚Äù This is disgusting. We must condemn these incidents, but we must do more.THREAD https://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2021/12/17/swastikas-found-in-bathroom-at-marlton-middle-school-superintendent-says/
